stream_context.summary: Kaze works on two levels. First, he finalizes the star names and creates a music-synced intro cutscene for 'Oily Boily Bay'. Then, he shifts to a new western-themed level, blocking out the area with placeholder geometry, designing a scavenger hunt mission, and undertaking a significant technical task to create, implement, and debug a system for multi-colored shortcut pipes.

development_findings.summary: Kaze pivots from blocking out a new western level to finalizing the star names and creating the intro cutscene for a nearly complete level, 'Oily Boily Bay'.
development_findings.quote: We're pausing this level. We're doing the intro cutscene for Oily Boily Bay.

development_findings.summary: When creating the intro cutscene for 'Oily Boily Bay', Kaze's primary focus is on meticulously timing the camera cuts to the beat of the level's music.
development_findings.quote: The most important part of the cutscene for me is that it's fitting to the music. So, which beat do we cut it on? That's the question.

development_findings.summary: The project has a hard technical constraint to keep the final ROM size under 64 megabytes to ensure it can run on original N64 hardware via a standard flashcart.
development_findings.quote: Yes, it is one of my conditions that it fits on a normal N64 cartridge. I'm not gonna go above 64 megabytes.

development_findings.summary: Kaze believes original N64 developers over-optimized for low polygon counts while neglecting more significant performance bottlenecks, resulting in games that are visually simpler than the hardware could have handled.
development_findings.quote: The people that made N64 games thought if they just made their stuff low-poly it would run better. And they never actually addressed the real issues that they had in their games. So all the N64 games are way too low-poly for their own good.

development_findings.summary: After a crash occurs while implementing custom warp pipes, Kaze uses the NEMU64 emulator to get the program counter at the time of the crash and directly debugs the issue by reading the assembly code, bypassing the need for C-level debug symbols.
development_findings.quote: The crash is in my code here and you don't really need debug symbols if you're just really really fucking good at assembling.

development_findings.summary: A scavenger hunt is designed for the western level, where the player finds a series of signs that provide clues sending them to different landmarks across the area.

Kaze designs and implements a system for colored warp pipes, using a custom geo layout that reads the object's b-param to set a tint color, allowing for multiple pipe colors using a single model and texture set.
The development workflow heavily utilizes a plugin called Fast64, which allows the team to convert and import models directly from Blender into the N64 game engine.
development_findings.quote: I can import directly from blender we have a plug-in for that code fast 64 it converts blender models to n64 models

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes a simple, frictionless, and non-frustrating platformer, similar in design philosophy to Mario Odyssey, would be extremely popular within the ROM hacking scene.
context_findings.quote: I have this theory that games are just so goddamn bad that if you make a game that is just not offensive to the player, just like an inoffensive easy platformer with no frustration, no friction, just like easily solvable everything, people will fucking love it.

context_findings.summary: Kaze acknowledges a history of conflict with another creator, Skalox, and has decided the best path forward is mutual avoidance. He references his name being censored in Skalox's Discord.
context_findings.quote: I think it is best if me and Skalox just do not acknowledge each other's existence anymore. I think we both fare off better like that.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses positive sentiment towards new Chinese regulations banning predatory monetization techniques in video games, such as daily login rewards and certain gacha mechanics.
context_findings.quote: Did you guys know that Xi Jinping recently saved video gaming? They are banning a bunch of predatory techniques in China.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses frustration with modern programming language trends that prioritize safety features at the cost of developer freedom and simplicity, comparing them negatively to the evolution of natural languages.
context_findings.quote: I hate when programming languages are making things more tedious to do just because they want to be safe. Like dude, just let me do my things. Like come on, just leave me alone.

context_findings.summary: Kaze becomes extremely frustrated with viewers repeatedly telling him to use the Parallel Launcher emulator, which he demonstrates does not work on his system, leading him to actively resent the software and its proponents.
context_findings.quote: I'm just gonna become the number one parallel launcher hater. Just because you guys keep telling me to use it.

context_findings.summary: Kaze mentions that dual-streaming to both Twitch and YouTube has resulted in a significant increase in viewership.

biobak.summary: Biobak is responsible for completing the visual assets and art for several areas, including the power generator and underground sections of 'Oily Boily Bay'.
biobak.quote: Biobak said he would finish this area. So this is a little unfinished right now.

biobak.summary: Kaze is facing issues paying Biobak through PayPal and is frustrated by the alternative of using cryptocurrency due to its fees and complexity for tax purposes.
biobak.quote: I still need to buy fucking crypto pay crypto fees just to pay Biobak and then he has to pay crypto fees too... I'd literally just rather send them a bank transfer.

badub.summary: Badub is the primary composer for the project's levels.
badub.quote: Who made the music for this level? Badub. He always makes the music for my levels. Nowadays at least.

zeina.summary: Zeina is creating a 3D model of a large skull to be used as a key setpiece in the new western-themed level.
zeina.quote: There will be a skull here that Zeina is working on right now.

zeina.summary: Kaze provides positive, real-time feedback on a skeleton model Zeina is working on, indicating a close collaborative loop.
zeina.quote: Oh, that looks really good, Zainer. I like that a lot. This is the skeleton, Zainer.

key_stories.title: The Parallel Launcher Confrontation
key_stories.summary: Kaze, fed up with constant suggestions to use the Parallel Launcher emulator, demonstrated on stream that it doesn't work on his system. This led to a heated exchange with his chat, culminating in him explaining his own emulation philosophy and vowing to become the 'number one parallel launcher hater' out of spite.
key_stories.challenge: The community and viewers persistently recommended Kaze use the Parallel Launcher emulator, despite him not wanting to.
key_stories.process: To address the constant suggestions, Kaze launched Parallel Launcher on stream. He demonstrated that it was not working correctly on his PC, with graphical glitches and an inability to control the character. He explained the history and purpose of the emulator (as a front-end for a Retroarch plugin) and argued with chat members who claimed it was 'user error'.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze's frustration boiled over, leading him to coin the term 'Parallel launcher tarts' for its proponents. He solidified his stance against using it, explaining his preferred, tiered approach to emulation for accuracy (N64 > NEMU64 > Ares/Simple64) and demonstrating that his current tools meet all his needs.
key_stories.key_quote: I'm so sick of this. How many times do I have to do this song and dance? Where I try and use the emulator and it doesn't work. No, you are coping.

key_stories.title: Implementing Colored Shortcut Pipes
key_stories.summary: To create shortcuts for the western level, Kaze designed a new, optimized pipe model. He developed a custom system to allow for different colors using a single model, which involved writing and debugging new code in assembly. He then iterated on the specific pipe colors to ensure they were distinct, even considering colorblind accessibility.
key_stories.challenge: The western level required a system of shortcut pipes that were visually distinct, good-looking on N64, and resource-efficient.
key_stories.process: Kaze started by creating a new pipe model and texture, iterating on its shape and shading to avoid a 'plastic' look. To enable color variations without multiple models, he created a custom geo layout that used an object's behavior parameter (`bparam2`) to apply a color. This new code introduced a crash, which he debugged using NEMU64 and assembly. Finally, he fine-tuned the four pipe colors (shades of yellow, orange, and red, plus gray) for visual distinction.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze successfully created a highly optimized, color-customizable pipe model. After considering colorblindness accessibility, he adjusted the hues to improve differentiability, deciding that minor ambiguity was acceptable for an optional shortcut mechanic.
key_stories.key_quote: The pipes really aren't that deep they're just shortcuts you can use to get around the level faster. You're entirely free not to interact with these.

key_stories.title: Syncing the Oily Boily Bay Cutscene
key_stories.summary: Kaze decided to create the intro cutscene for 'Oily Boily Bay' on the spot. His primary goal was to sync the camera cuts perfectly to the level's music. Through an iterative process of placing camera splines and adjusting their timing frame-by-frame, he produced a short but effective cutscene that matched the musical beats.
key_stories.challenge: The 'Oily Boily Bay' level needed a polished intro cutscene to establish its industrial, oppressive atmosphere.
key_stories.process: Kaze paused work on another level to focus on this task. He listened to the level's music repeatedly to identify the key beats for camera cuts. He planned the shotsâ€”a pan from buildings to a large Bowser statue, a close-up on the statue, and a pan over some scaffolds. He then implemented these using splines in the engine and iteratively tweaked the timing of each cut by a few frames until it felt perfectly aligned with the music.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze successfully created a short, three-shot intro cutscene that he was happy with. The final sequence was perfectly synchronized with the music's beat changes, effectively setting the mood for the level.
key_stories.key_quote: The most important part of the cutscene for me is that it's fitting to the music. So, which beat do we cut it on? That's the question.
